Graphical abstract The graphical abstract outlines the synthesis methods of high-entropy materials (HEMs) and their versatile applications in solid oxide cells (SOCs), including air/fuel electrodes, electrolytes, and interconnects. It also highlights their multifunctionality and future potential in advancing SOC technology. As global energy demand increases and environmental standards tighten, the development of efficient, eco-friendly energy conversion and storage technologies becomes crucial. Solid oxide cells (SOCs) show great promise because of their high energy conversion efficiency and wide range of applications. High-entropy materials (HEMs), a novel class of materials comprising several principal elements, have attracted significant interest within the materials science and energy sectors. Their distinctive structural features and adaptable functional properties offer immense potential for innovation across various applications. This review systematically covers the basic concepts, crystal structures, element selection, and major synthesis strategies of HEMs, and explores in detail the specific applications of these materials in SOCs, including its potential as air electrodes, fuel electrodes, electrolytes, and interconnects (including barrier coatings). By analyzing existing studies, this review reveals the significant advantages of HEMs in enhancing the performance, anti-poisoning, and stability of SOCs; highlights the key areas and challenges for future research; and looks into possible future directions. Keywords Solid oxide cells High-entropy materials Air electrodes Fuel electrodes Electrolytes Interconnects 1 Introduction In recent years, the world has faced a severe energy crisis due to the overdependence on finite fossil fuels. Overreliance on fossil fuels has led to a multitude of severe environmental problems, including climate change, air pollution, and acid rain, which have significantly affected global economy and societies [1,2]. As globalization intensifies, the scope of these challenges is expanding. As a result, the broad adoption of renewable energy sources and the development of green technologies, such as fuel cells and hydrogen generators, have emerged as effective solutions to address these environmental challenges [3,4]. Solid oxide cells (SOCs) represent a revolutionary advancement in the energy field, offering major advantages such as high conversion efficiency, environmental sustainability, and versatility across multiple applications [5–7]. SOCs function in two modes: as solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) to generate electricity from various fuels such as hydrogen, natural gas, and other hydrocarbons, or as solid oxide electrolysis cells (SOECs) to produce hydrogen and other fuels (NH3, CH4, C2H4, etc.) using renewable energy sources such as wind and solar power [8]. Unlike traditional power generation methods that rely on combustion, SOCs achieve energy conversion through electrochemical reactions, significantly improving energy utilization efficiency and reducing the emission of harmful substances, including nitrogen oxides, sulfides, and carbon oxides. A typical SOC comprises a porous oxide-based air (oxygen) electrode, a dense oxide-based electrolyte that conducts either oxygen ions (O2−) or protons (H+), and a porous metal-ceramic composite fuel (hydrogen) electrode, arranged in a sandwich structure with an intermediate electrolyte. SOCs can be categorized into two types depending on the ions conducted by the electrolyte: oxygen ion-based solid oxide cells (O-SOCs) (Fig. 1 a) and proton-based solid oxide cells (P-SOCs), also known as proton ceramic cells (PCCs) (Fig. 1b) [9]. O-SOCs operate at higher temperatures (700–1000 °C), whereas P-SOCs operate at medium temperatures (400–700 °C), which are lower than those of O-SOCs, offering the benefits of reduced electrode material degradation and improved system compatibility [10,11]. Fig. 1 schematically illustrates the working principles of these two SOC types. In fuel cell (FC) mode, fuel undergoes hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) at the fuel electrode, releasing electrons. These electrons travel through an external circuit to the air electrode, where they participate in the electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). O2− or H+ traverses the solid electrolyte, moving from one electrode to the other (O2− at the fuel electrode, H+ at the air electrode), thereby completing the final reaction. In electrolysis cell (EC) mode, the reverse process occurs, with oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the air electrode and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at the fuel electrode. The fundamental sub-reactions of each reaction are listed in Table 1 [12,13]. In comparison to low-temperature fuel cells, such as proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and alkaline fuel cells (AFCs), which operate between room temperature and 80 °C and rely heavily on precious metal catalysts like platinum, the higher operating temperature of SOCs (400–1000 °C) significantly enhances the kinetics of electrode reactions [14]. This allows for the use of nonprecious metal catalysts, which reduces the overall system cost. Moreover, SOCs offer greater fuel flexibility, accommodating a wide variety of fuels, including hydrocarbons (e.g., methane and ethane) [15], formic acid [16], ethanol [17], ammonia [18], and hydrogen, directly for power generation. However, the increase in operating temperature also presents challenges for SOCs, as conventional SOC component materials face a range of issues, including insufficient electrode morphology stability, mismatch in thermal expansion between components, and inadequate thermomechanical stability. To address these challenges, the components of SOCs must be fabricated using advanced functional materials [19]. Recently, a new category of materials referred to as high-entropy materials (HEMs) has garnered significant attention within the scientific community (Fig. 2 a). The high-entropy concept emerged with the discovery of high-entropy alloys (HEAs) by Yeh et al. [20] and Cantor et al. [21] in 2004. HEAs are defined as single-phase solid-solution alloys composed of five or more principal elements in nearly equimolar ratios. Notable examples include the HEA CuCoNiCrAl x Fe synthesized by Yeh et al. [20] and the CrMnFeCoNi system developed by Cantor et al. [21]. Over the past two decades, researchers have reported various HEMs, including HEAs [22–24], high-entropy oxides (HEOs) [25–30], high-entropy borides (HEBs) [31], high-entropy nitrides (HENs) [32], high-entropy carbides (HECs) [33], high-entropy silicides (HESs) [34] and other high-entropy composites (Fig. 2b). HEMs have been widely utilized in the energy sector because of their unique properties, such as excellent oxidation resistance, high-temperature stability, corrosion resistance, and good thermal conductivity. Consequently, novel medium- and high-entropy materials, including electrolytes, air electrodes, fuel electrodes, and protective coatings for SOC interconnects, have been developed to meet these demands. Recently, numerous reviews [35–39] have summarized the current research and applications of HEMs across various fields, including hydrogen storage, electrocatalysis, sodium-ion batteries, lithium-ion batteries, supercapacitors. Pikalova et al. [40] provided an overview of the theoretical foundations, synthesis, and accomplishments of HEMs in SOFCs. Given the rapid advancements and increasing adoption of HEMs in SOCs, a thorough and updated review is essential, focusing on high-entropy design and synthesis strategies, the impact of different site entropy engineering on electrochemical performance and function, and detailed perspectives on future research directions. Herein, this review summarized the various latest applications of HEMs in SOCs (Fig. 3 ). It begins by introducing the concept of high entropy, followed by an analysis of the common synthesis methods of HEMs. The diverse applications of HEMs in SOCs are then summarized, and the current challenges of using HEMs as SOC components are proposed. Finally, perspectives on future research directions are offered. This review aims to provide researchers with valuable, up-to-date information and guidance for further development. 2 Concept of high entropy The first reported HEMs were HEAs [20,21]. HEAs are defined as solid solutions that include at least five principal metal elements, with each element comprising 5% to 35% of the atomic composition [21]. This definition implicitly includes minor metal elements with atomic percentages below 5% [22]. While this definition is based on the elemental concentration, another definition is derived from the concept of configurational entropy (ΔS config) [49]. The ΔS config of the solid solution can be expressed as a function of the number of elements in the solid solution. The ΔS config of a solid solution can be expressed as (1) Δ S c o n f i g = - R ∑ i = 1 N x i l n x i where R is the universal gas constant (R = 8.314 J mol−1 K−1), N is the number of elements in the perovskite structure, and xi is the molar fraction of element i. HEAs are defined as solid solutions with ΔS config greater than 1.5 R in their stoichiometric state. Thus, materials with ΔS config greater than 1.5 R are considered HEMs. Those with ΔS config values between 1.0 R and 1.5 R are classified as medium-entropy materials, whereas materials with the ΔS config values below 1.0 R are categorized as low-entropy materials (Fig. 4 ) [50]. In thermodynamics, the Gibbs-Helmholtz equation is given by (2) Δ G m i x = Δ H m i x - T Δ S m i x where ΔG mix represents the change in Gibbs free energy, ΔH mix represents the change in mixing enthalpy, ΔS mix represents the change in configurational entropy, and T represents the absolute temperature of the system. There is a competition between the increased configurational entropy (ΔS mix) described by the Gibbs-Helmholtz equation and the additional enthalpy required to mix the different elements (ΔH mix). If the contribution of configurational entropy (TΔS mix) can balance or exceed the enthalpy contribution (ΔH mix), then ΔG mix becomes more negative [35,51]. This leads to the stabilization of the crystal structure through increased configurational entropy, thus enhancing the stability of the compound. In the high-entropy concept, the change in configurational entropy depends solely on the number of incorporated elements, so that for a given number of elements, higher temperatures can make ΔG mix more negative, resulting in increased structural stability [27]. Entropy stabilization occurs only when entropy dominates the thermodynamic environment, regulating the structure and phase behavior. Additionally, other entropic effects may play a significant role in stabilizing certain phases. Notably, overcompensation does not always result in the formation of single-phase materials, as local energy minima may hinder elemental doping, sometimes leading to the formation of multicomponent phases [52]. Moreover, some thermodynamically unstable non-high-entropy materials, such as Bi2Ti2O7, which is unstable in the Bi2O3-TiO2 phase diagram, can also become stable by increasing entropy [35]. Rost et al. [41] demonstrated that removing any of the cations from (MgCoNiCuZn)O crystals leads to polyphase materials under all reaction conditions, indicating the failure to form an entropy-stabilized system where TΔS mix cannot compensate for the effect of ΔH mix. 3 Physical and chemical properties of HEMs Another advantage of HEMs is their structural diversity. Various crystal structures have been reported for HEAs, including body-centered cubic (bcc), face-centered cubic (fcc), and hexagonal close-packed (hcp) structures, see Fig. 5 (a). The structure and effects of HEAs largely determine their properties. For example, the CoFeMnTi x V y Zr z HEA reported by Kao et al. [53] exhibits a C14 Laves phase, which enhances hydrogen absorption and desorption, making it highly promising for hydrogen energy applications. The slow diffusion effect in HEAs results in the formation of nanocrystalline or even amorphous structures, which have considerable potential in electrocatalysis [54–57], including the HER, OER, ORR, and alcohol oxidation reactions (MOR/EOR). Overall, HEAs can be considered atomic-level composites, where the combination of multiple principal metals and the interactions between different elements result in a synergistic (cocktail) effect on their properties. The development of HEOs has added further diversity to the field. In 2015, Rost et al. [41] introduced a high-entropy oxide with a rock salt structure, (MgCoNiCuZn)O, extending the concept of entropy stabilization to multicomponent oxides and inspiring a wave of new HEO research. Since then, various HEO structures have been designed and synthesized [29,58], including but not limited to rock salt, fluorite, spinel, pyrochlore, hydrotalcite, jasper, and chalcopyrite (Fig. 5b). Unlike HEAs, which often have random atomic distributions similar to pure metals [59], HEOs typically exhibit distinct crystal structures and multiple valence states, resulting in unique structural arrangements that contribute to diverse properties. This structural diversity allows HEOs to exhibit a wide array of physical and chemical properties not achievable with simpler metal structures [30,60,61]. Understanding the structure of HEMs is crucial, but selecting their constituent elements is equally significant. Element composition greatly influences the performance of HEMs, affecting phase stability, mechanical strength, and electrochemical behavior. Consequently, an analysis of element usage frequencies in HEAs is presented, as shown in Fig. 5c [24]. The colored regions indicate elements currently used, with transition metals like iron, cobalt, nickel, and chromium being common due to their abundance, cost-effectiveness, and excellent catalytic properties. Additionally, elements utilized at different sites in HEOs are summarized in Fig. 5d [62]. For example, A-site elements in perovskite oxides typically include larger cations like Ba or Sr, which stabilize the crystal structure and enhance ionic conductivity. B-site elements generally consist of transition metals like Co or Mn, which can improve catalytic performance due to variable oxidation states. At the O-site, elements such as oxygen (O), and occasionally anions like chloride (Cl) or fluoride (F), play a crucial role. Oxygen enables oxygen ion transport, essential for ionic conductivity and redox reactions, while chloride and fluoride further modify the local charge environment, enhancing both electronic and ionic transport through unique anion-cation interactions. This strategic selection of elements ensures that HEMs exhibit superior structural integrity and enhanced electrochemical properties, ultimately improving efficiency in SOC applications. The chaotic atomic distribution in HEMs imparts several general advantages over conventional materials, driven by four primary effects: (i) high entropy effects in thermodynamics, (ii) lattice distortion effects in the structure, (iii) retarded diffusion effects in kinetics, and (iv) “cocktail” effects in performance [20]. Together, these effects grant HEMs remarkable structural stability, superior mechanical properties, and thermal resilience, making them ideal for applications demanding high durability and performance. For example, HEAs exhibit exceptional strength and structural stability even at elevated temperatures, low thermal conductivity, retained plasticity, and markedly slower elemental diffusion compared to traditional alloys [20,21]. Specifically, the significant lattice distortion in HEAs hinders dislocation movement, which enhances hardness and wear resistance. The sluggish diffusion of elements, resulting from localized stress and high migration energy barriers, facilitates the formation of nanoscale structures within the alloy, providing additional mechanical stability [20]. Furthermore, the “cocktail” effect, arising from the interplay of multiple elements, yields properties that are distinctly different—and often superior—to those of any single constituent, such as enhanced corrosion resistance and tailored electrochemical properties [63]. This combination of effects underscores the versatile potential of HEMs to surpass the limitations of conventional materials, particularly in applications that benefit from their unique thermal, structural, and functional attributes. 4 Synthesis of HEMs The synthesis of HEMs presents a significantly greater challenge compared to conventional materials. While conventional materials typically consist of one or a few elements, with preparation processes primarily focused on purity and composition control, HEMs contain five or more principal elements, often in near-equimolar ratios, each with distinct physicochemical properties. This complexity requires careful mixing and strict control over the homogeneous distribution of elements during synthesis to achieve the desired material characteristics [25]. Currently, HEM synthesis methods can be broadly classified into three categories: solid-state methods, wet chemical methods, and gas-phase methods. This section provides an overview of these synthesis techniques, discussing their respective advantages and limitations (Table 2 ) to offer insights for future research and potential applications in this evolving field. 4.1 Synthesis methods of HEAs The synthesis of HEAs generally involves combining multiple metal elements, either in the solid or liquid state, to form a stable, homogeneous alloy. This often requires high-temperature melting followed by controlled cooling to ensure the formation of a polycrystalline structure [64]. While HEA synthesis shares similarities with methods used for amorphous alloys, the key distinction lies in achieving a well-mixed solid solution with distinct crystalline phases. Common techniques for HEA preparation include solid-state reaction (SSR), laser cladding, magnetron sputtering, and vacuum arc melting (VAM), each offering specific advantages depending on the desired material properties. Laser cladding technology is widely used for precision material processing, particularly in the preparation of wear- and corrosion-resistant surface coatings, making it a key method in surface engineering. This technique has also been applied to the fabrication of thin films of HEAs [65,66]. It utilizes a high-energy laser beam to melt and deposit powdered HEAs onto a substrate surface, forming a dense coating (Fig. 6 a). The rapid solidification of the melt pool enables the formation of fine microstructures and homogeneous alloy compositions, which enhance the mechanical properties of the coating. For example, Jin et al. [67] successfully prepared FeNiCoAlCu-coated HEAs via laser cladding and reported that the coating retained excellent wear resistance at high temperatures. Additionally, magnetron sputtering is another method employed for synthesizing HEA thin films [68,69]. This technique utilizes a magnetic field to intensify the sputtering effect, where high-energy ions bombard a target material, dislodging atoms that are subsequently deposited onto a substrate to form an alloy film (Fig. 6b). Magnetron sputtering allows for precise control over the film thickness and composition, making it suitable for applications requiring uniform and high-quality HEA coatings, such as in electronics, catalysis, and protective layers. Vacuum arc melting (VAM) is a widely used method for synthesizing HEAs due to its ability to produce homogeneous alloys with complex compositions [70,71]. In this process, pre-weighed metal blocks of the desired elements are placed in a water-cooled copper crucible. The system operates under a vacuum or an inert gas atmosphere (such as argon) to prevent oxidation. An electric arc is generated by high-voltage discharges between electrodes, creating a high-temperature zone that rapidly melts the metal elements. The arc produces temperatures sufficient to melt even refractory metals, ensuring thorough mixing of the molten metals. Once fully homogenized, the molten alloy is cooled and solidified to form the HEA (Fig. 6c). VAM offers several advantages: it achieves extremely high temperatures, enables rapid melting, and ensures homogeneity in the final product. This makes it ideal for synthesizing HEA blocks with complex elemental compositions, which are challenging to achieve using conventional melting techniques. Additionally, VAM allows for the precise control of alloying elements, making it suitable for research and industrial applications where custom alloy compositions are required. The high-temperature liquid-phase shock (HTLS) technique enables the rapid synthesis of HEAs in a liquid medium within a reactor operating at temperatures up to 750 K. This method overcomes the temperature limitations of conventional liquid-phase reactions, allowing for enhanced structural modulation of nanocatalysts. The HTLS technique is particularly effective for producing high-quality HEA nanostructures with novel phases, controlled defects, and tailored elemental distributions. By inducing rapid thermal shocks in the liquid phase, it facilitates the formation of ultrafine, crystalline HEA nanoparticles with unique properties. Cui et al. [72] utilized this method to synthesize ultrafine HEA nanoparticles of PtCoNiRuIr, with a size of 3.24 nm, customized elemental composition, and crystalline phases with precisely controlled lattice strains (Fig. 6d). The HTLS technique offers a promising route for fabricating advanced HEA nanocatalysts with optimized performance for electrochemical applications. In order to analyze the advantages and disadvantages of these synthesis methods, a comprehensive evaluation was carried out from the aspects of efficiency, cost, expansibility and product characteristics [73,74]. Laser cladding technology offers high precision and control over particle size and composition, producing dense, pure HEM coatings; however, the cost and complexity of equipment are considerable, and scalability remains challenging due to its spot-based processing. Magnetron sputtering is advantageous for high-purity thin films with consistent composition, but it requires specialized equipment with high initial costs, and productivity is relatively low due to slow deposition rates, limiting scalability. VAM is cost-effective for bulk HEM production with high purity and homogeneity. The equipment requirements are moderate compared to other advanced methods, and VAM is relatively scalable. However, it is less effective for producing fine particles or specific particle sizes, and post-processing may be necessary. HTLS synthesis is productive and cost-effective for generating nanoscale HEMs with controlled particle sizes, requiring less processing time than other methods. Despite this, maintaining product purity can be challenging due to potential contamination from shock-derived byproducts, and achieving uniformity at scale is difficult, limiting its broader applicability for large-scale HEM synthesis. 4.2 Synthesis methods of HEOs The synthesis methods of HEOs differ in several aspects from those of HEAs, primarily due to differences in their material properties and the specific process conditions required. Nevertheless, many of the strategies developed for HEAs can also be adapted for the synthesis of HEOs, particularly in terms of high-temperature processing and elemental mixing. The key distinction often lies in the desired form of the resulting material, whether it is bulk solid, powder, or thin film, as each form may require tailored synthesis approaches. This section will explore the various synthesis techniques employed for HEOs, highlighting both the similarities to HEA methods and the unique challenges posed by oxide materials. The solid-state reaction (SSR) method, widely used for synthesizing HEAs, is also the most conventional and commonly employed technique for the synthesis of HEOs. This method typically involves the thorough mixing of metal oxide precursors, pressing the mixture with a hydraulic press, and subjecting it to high-temperature calcination. For instance, Rost et al. [41] were the first to successfully synthesize a high-entropy oxide, (Mg0.2Co0.2Cu0.2Ni0.2Zn0.2)O, using commercial MgO, CoO, CuO, NiO, and ZnO as precursors. These were blended via ball milling for 2 h, after which 0.5 g samples were pressed into 1.27 cm round pieces under 31,000 N of force. This process enabled the formation of a single-phase material at relatively low temperatures (900–1100 °C). The results demonstrated that equimolar mixtures of metal oxides, heat-treated above 900 °C under high-entropy conditions, form a single rock salt phase with disordered cation arrangements. The metastable rock salt structure can persist at room temperature due to the retarded diffusion effect following rapid cooling, resulting in a stable high-entropy state. Recently, Chen et al. [75] advanced this method by synthesizing an entropy-stabilized metal oxide (NiMgCuZnCo)O using a modified mechanochemical approach at room temperature. This mechanochemical milling process successfully crystallized the single-phase (NiMgCuZnCo)O without requiring additional heat treatment, relying solely on mechanical energy and frictional heating, as shown in Fig. 7 (a). This fast, solvent-free method offers an efficient alternative to conventional SSR synthesis. The sol–gel method, sometimes referred to as the solution combustion method, is a widely used technique for synthesizing HEOs due to its ability to produce homogeneous materials with controlled porosity and morphology. The process begins with the dissolution of metal precursors in a solvent, followed by gelation through the formation of a three-dimensional network as the solution polymerizes. The resulting gel is then dried to remove solvents, after which it undergoes sintering or calcination at high temperatures to induce crystallization and densification (Fig. 7b). Wang et al. [76] successfully synthesized spherical mesoporous (NiCoCrFeMn)O high-entropy oxides with a spinel structure via this sol–gel strategy. These oxides displayed a high specific surface area of 143 m2/g, with pore sizes between 5.5 and 8.3 nm and a distinctive spherical morphology of approximately 55 nm. The sol–gel method is highly versatile, enabling the tuning of material properties through careful control of precursor concentrations and processing conditions. Spark plasma sintering (SPS) is a rapid and efficient method for sintering powder materials by applying pulsed electric currents and mechanical pressure simultaneously, leading to instantaneous high temperatures. The electric current induces localized heating at particle contact points, causing the surface layers of the particles to melt and form a transient liquid phase, while the applied pressure accelerates particle densification. This combination results in highly dense structures in much shorter times compared to conventional sintering methods. For example, Sr((Zr0.94Y0.06)0.2Sn0.2Ti0.2Hf0.2Mn0.2)O3– δ synthesized via SPS for just 9 min at 1475 °C showed a significantly denser microstructure compared to the same material produced by a conventional solid-state reaction [77]. Mao et al. [78] utilized a similar technique, reactive flash sintering (RFS) (Fig. 7c), to synthesize pyrochlore-structured high-entropy oxide (La0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Eu0.2Gd0.2)2Zr2O7, achieving a density of up to 99% in just seconds at 1200 °C. In contrast to traditional solid-state sintering, which typically requires 6 h at 1600 °C, RFS produced HEOs with exceptional atomic-level compositional homogeneity and superior mechanical properties, including enhanced modulus, hardness, and fracture toughness. In the sonochemical synthesis method, a mixture of metal salts is dissolved in a base within an ultrasonic vessel, followed by sonication for a specified duration. During this process, acoustic cavitation—rapid formation, growth, and collapse of bubbles—induces localized high temperatures and pressures, promoting the formation of single-phase HEO nanoparticles. After sonication, the precipitate is separated by centrifugation, washed, and dried to obtain the HEO product, often without the need for calcination (Fig. 7d). This method offers the advantage of producing highly crystalline nanoparticles with minimal thermal treatment. For example, Okejiri et al. [79] crystallized BaSr(ZrHfTi)O3, BaSrBi(ZrHfTiFe)O3, and Ru/BaSrBi(ZrHfTiFe)O3 nanoparticles into a single-phase perovskite structure through ultrasonic treatment. Sonochemical synthesis is a promising approach due to its energy efficiency and the ability to fine-tune particle size and composition through control of sonication parameters. Flame spray pyrolysis (FSP) (Fig. 7e) [80] and atomized spray pyrolysis (ASP) (Fig. 7f) [81] can be used to synthesize HEO nanoparticles. The key difference between the two lies in their heat sources: FSP uses a flame as the heat source, with the precursor solution combusting in the flame to produce high-temperature conditions (often above 1000 °C), leading to rapid formation of highly crystalline and uniform nanoparticles. In contrast, ASP relies on an external heat source, such as an electric furnace, to heat atomized droplets, allowing for greater control over temperature and atmosphere but typically yielding larger, less uniform particles with a broader size distribution. FSP typically uses combustible precursors, whereas ASP can handle a wider range of non-combustible solutions. While FSP is favored for rapid, high-quality nanoparticle synthesis, especially for catalysis and energy materials, ASP excels in scalable production, offering flexibility in precursor choice and particle morphology control. Reverse co-precipitation (RCP) involves mixing a solution of multiple metal salts, followed by the controlled addition of an alkaline precipitant, such as sodium hydroxide or ammonia, to induce the simultaneous precipitation of metal hydroxides. The rate of precipitant addition, pH, and temperature are critical parameters that influence the homogeneity of the resulting precursor. Under optimized conditions, the precipitates are then filtered, washed to remove impurities, and dried. The final step involves calcination at high temperatures to promote solid-state reactions and crystallization, leading to the formation of HEOs (Fig. 7g) [82]. This method offers simplicity and scalability, though careful control of conditions is necessary to ensure uniformity in composition and particle size, especially for multi-component systems. In summary, each method has its own unique advantages and limitations [73,74]. Specifically, SSR is a cost-effective and scalable synthesis method for SOC materials with minimal equipment requirements; however, it requires high temperatures and prolonged processing times, often resulting in larger particle sizes and lower purity. Modified mechanochemical approaches offer low-cost and energy-efficient synthesis of high-purity nanoscale HEMs, with moderate equipment requirements; however, scalability is limited, as achieving uniform mixing at larger scales remains challenging. Sol-gel methods allow fine control over particle size and morphology, producing high-purity materials, but involve complex processing steps and costly precursors, and achieving scalability is a challenge due to the batch nature of the process. SPS achieves rapid densification and fine particle control with high productivity, but the cost of specialized equipment and moderate scalability can be barriers, especially for larger batches. RFS offers ultra-fast sintering and lower temperatures, promoting homogeneity and purity, yet high-cost equipment and limited scalability present challenges. Sonochemical synthesis is an energy-efficient and scalable technique for producing nanoparticles at low cost, but product purity can vary due to potential byproduct formation, and control over particle size may be limited. RCP is a scalable, cost-effective wet chemical method that can achieve uniform particle sizes; however, it requires precise pH control, and achieving high purity may need further washing and calcination steps. FSP and ASP both offer high productivity and scalability with controlled particle size, where FSP excels in producing highly crystalline, uniform nanoparticles, but its high operating temperatures raise costs. ASP, with moderate temperature requirements, offers more flexibility but yields particles with a broader size distribution, and controlling purity may require additional purification steps. Overall, each method presents a unique combination of advantages and trade-offs based on the desired HEM characteristics and application scale. 5 Application of HEMs in SOCs 5.1 HEMs as SOC fuel electrodes Fuel oxidation or combustion takes place on the fuel electrode side. Therefore, the fuel electrode must exhibit high electrocatalytic activity for fuel oxidation and adequate catalytic activity for hydrocarbon reforming [86,87]. In recent decades, nickel-based fuel electrodes, such as Ni-(Y2O3)0.08(ZrO2)0.92 (Ni-YSZ) and Ni-BaZr0.1Ce0.7Y0.1Yb0.1O3– δ (Ni-BZCYYb) [88,89], have been widely utilized in SOCs because of the excellent electrical conductivity and catalytic properties of nickel [90]. However, Ni-based fuel electrodes face challenges, including deactivation due to sulfur impurities and degradation caused by reoxidation or carbon deposition in CO2 or hydrocarbon fuels [91–93]. Therefore, developing fuel electrode materials for SOCs with improved catalytic activity and long-term stability is crucial. The essential requirements for SOC fuel electrode materials are summarized as follows [40,87]: (i) a large surface area at the three-phase boundary (TPB) to maximize the anodic reaction; (ii) enhanced porosity to facilitate gas transport (about 50% for supported fuel electrode layers and about 35% for functional fuel electrode layers); (iii) stability in a reducing atmosphere; (iv) high electrical conductivity (100 S cm−1 or higher); (v) thermal compatibility with other cell construction materials; (vi) high electrocatalytic activity for hydroxide reactions; and (vii) some resistance to coking and sulfur resistance. In this subsection, the application of HEAs and HEOs in SOC fuel electrodes is introduced. SOCs offer multifuel flexibility, supporting various fuels such as syngas, biogas, natural gas, other hydrocarbons, and pure hydrogen [94]. This versatility places high demands on the resistance of the fuel electrode to carbon buildup. Conventional SOCs utilizing nickel-based fuel electrodes offer high electronic conductivity and excellent electrocatalytic performance; however, the volume expansion of nickel during oxidation can lead to irreversible cell cracking, especially with long-term operation [95]. Additionally, the rapid heat absorption and thermal stress from hydrocarbon reforming can cause cell rupture and carbon buildup due to overcooling [96,97]. To address these issues, several Ni alloy cermets, including Ni-Cu-YSZ [98] and Ni-Cu-Sm0.2Ce0.8O2 (SDC) [99], have been developed as fuel electrode materials for SOCs. These materials demonstrate excellent electrical conductivity and superior flexibility toward hydrocarbon fuels. For example, a catalytic layer of Ni-Fe alloy on the surface of a Ni-based fuel electrode significantly inhibits nickel oxidation and improves cell durability [100]. Similarly, the Ni-Co alloy demonstrates excellent redox tolerance owing to the formation of a dense oxide film that protects against nickel oxidation. Although alloys provide better stability than pure nickel, the current progress with binary alloys remains limited. Recently, HEAs have emerged as promising fuel electrode materials for SOCs because of their excellent catalytic activity, durability, and resistance to carbon buildup. Chen et al. reported the use of the HEA FeCoNiCuX (X = Al, Mo) as a fuel electrode for medium-temperature SOCs [101]. In their study, the FeCoNiCuAl-SDC electrode with a La0.8Sr0.2Ga0.8Mg0.2O3– δ (LSGM) electrolyte-supported single cell demonstrated peak power density (PPD) values of 779 and 526 mW cm−2 for H2 and CH4 as fuel gases, respectively, at 850 °C. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) revealed that the various valence states of the primary elements in the FeCoNiCuX HEA generate more active sites with synergistic effects on H2, CH4, H2O, and CO. In another study, Tong et al. [102] synthesized a similar HEA, Fe0.1Co0.35Ni0.35Cu0.1Mo0.1 (FCNCM), as a fuel electrode material for SOECs used in the co-electrolysis of H2O and CO2 to produce syngas. The YSZ-supported single cell with the FCNCM-Gd0.1Ce0.9O2– δ (GDC) composite fuel electrode achieved a PPD of 480 mW cm−2 in FC mode at 850 °C, which was over 20% higher than that of conventional Ni-GDC cells. Additionally, it reached an operating current density of 878 mA cm−2 at a co-electrolysis voltage of 1.5 V with a H2O/CO2 gas ratio of 2/1, which is 18% higher than that of Ni-based cells. Compared with that in Ni-based cells, the proportion of CO in the co-electrolysis product also increased significantly. The FCNCM-GDC electrode exhibited 110 h of stability at a current density of 0.5 A cm−2, with improved performance attributed to the in-situ formation of a spinel phase under oxidizing conditions, which helps prevent cell degradation. Furthermore, HEAs have shown potential as catalysts for hydrocarbon reforming. Lee et al. [103] synthesized HEA fuel electrodes and methane reforming catalysts comprising Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Mn loaded on GDC. Steam reforming of methane was carried out under SOFC operating conditions. While the conversion of HEA-GDC at 700 °C was lower than that of Ni-YSZ and Ni-GDC, it exhibited superior stability with no signs of carbon deposition. This highlights the inherent robustness of HEA-GDC, its strong resistance to carbon buildup, and its stable catalytic performance, positioning it as a promising fuel electrode candidate for direct utilization of hydrocarbon fuels in SOC applications. The composite perovskite oxide SOC fuel electrodes should demonstrate strong chemical stability, sufficient electronic conductivity, and exceptional catalytic activity for the oxidation of fuel gases [104–106]. For example, the development of long-term stable fuel electrodes based on Sr2Fe1.5Mo0.5O6 (SFM) with double perovskite structures is of significant interest [107]. Ma et al. combined the high electronic conductivity of Sr2V1.5Mo0.5O6 (SVM) with the strong catalytic activity and adequate ionic conductivity of SFM to prepare the B-site MEO SrV1/3Fe1/3Mo1/3O3 (SVFMO) via solid-phase reaction [108]. The electrical conductivity of SVFMO ranges from 508.4 to 207 S cm−1 over a temperature range of 30 to 800 °C. Additionally, SVFMO has an average thermal expansion coefficient (TEC) value of 17.7 × 10−6 K−1 over the 30–800 °C range, which ensures that SVFMO can expand and contract at a rate compatible with that of widely used electrolyte materials such as YSZ, LSGM, and SDC. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) studies of symmetric cells using SVMO, SFMO, and SVFMO fuel electrodes revealed R p values of 0.825, 0.522, and 0.371 Ω cm2, respectively, at 850 °C. The reduced R p of SVFMO can be attributed to its enhanced catalytic activity and more efficient charge carrier transport, stemming from an increase in the number of oxygen vacancies and the presence of small polarizer pairs. Overall, SVFMO is a promising fuel electrode material for SOCs, providing strong conductivity and effective catalytic activity for fuel oxidation. In EC mode, SOCs can convert CO2 into chemical fuels or other high-value chemicals through the CO2 electrochemical reduction reaction (CO2RR) (Fig. 8 a) [109–111]. However, the slow kinetics and uncontrollable selectivity of the CO2RR limit its commercial application because of the thermodynamic stability of the CO2 molecule and the complexity of multiple electron processes. Recently, high-entropy perovskite oxides (HEPOs) have emerged as electrode materials with high CO2RR activity owing to their structural tolerance, multicomponent synergies, and conformational entropy effects. For example, a high-entropy Ruddlesden-Popper type layered perovskite, Pr0.8Sr1.2(CuFe)0.4Mo0.2Mn0.2Nb0.2O4– δ (HE-PSCFMMN), was reported as a fuel electrode for SOECs, featuring a uniform coating of in situ exsolved CuFe alloy@FeO (CFA@FeO) core–shell structured particles (Fig. 8c) [112]. This material was prepared by reducing the cubic Pr0.4Sr0.6Cu0.3Fe0.4Mo0.1Mn0.1Nb0.1O3– δ (PSCFMMN) perovskite in H2 at 800 °C (Fig. 8b). As the operating voltage increased from the open-circuit voltage (OCV) to 1.5 V at 800 °C, the cell with the HE-PSCFMMN-CFA@FeO electrode achieved a current density of 2.27 A cm−2 (Fig. 8d). Additionally, at 800 °C, the cell with HE-PSCFMMN-CFA@FeO electrode achieved stability for over 200 h under a constant output current of 0.75 A cm−2. This sustained performance highlights the electrode’s durability and potential suitability for long-term SOC operation under high current densities. The enhancement of electrochemical performance is attributed to the uniform coverage of CFA@FeO nanoparticles on the surface of the HE-PSCFMMN electrode. These nanoparticles formed multiple CFA@FeO/HE-PSCFMMN heterointerfaces, serving as active sites for CO2 adsorption, dissociation, and electrolysis. The researchers developed three distinct models: SFO (SrFeO3– δ ), RP-SFO, and RP-SFO@FeO. Among these, the CO2 reacted on the surface of RP-SFO@FeO with the lowest energy barrier (Fig. 8e), which was consistent with the results of the electrochemical performance tests. This confirmed that the HE-PSCFMMN-CFA@FeO electrode material demonstrated improved CO2 electrolysis performance. Additionally, an in situ-formed metal/high-entropy perovskite heterointerface, NiFe@Sr2Fe0.4V0.4Mo0.4Ni0.4Ti0.6O6– δ (SFVMNT), was proposed by He et al. [113] to increase the CO2RR (Fig. 8f–h). The NiFe alloy underwent in situ exsolution in a reducing atmosphere, causing the crystal structure to shift from a scheelite phase to a cubic perovskite phase. The symmetric SOEC supported with an LSGM electrolyte achieved a current density of 1.66 A cm−2 at 800 °C and 1.5 V (Fig. 8i). This is attributed to the in-situ formation of the NiFe alloy on the surface, which increased the concentration of oxygen vacancies and promoted the interaction between CO2 molecules and the oxygen vacancies. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that the CO2RR consists of three basic steps (Fig. 8j): CO2 adsorption (ΔG 1 = −1.10 eV), *CO2 dissociation into *CO (ΔG 2 = 1.29 eV), and CO desorption (ΔG 3 = −1.88 eV), with the second step being the rate-limiting step. Previously, they also developed a MEO based on SFM, Sr2FeTi0.25Cr0.25Mn0.25Mo0.25O6– δ (SFTCMM), as an electrode material for symmetric SOECs [114]. Oxygen vacancies are essential for ionic conductivity and reactivity of materials. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed that SFTCMM results in more weight loss, indicating a greater likelihood of oxygen vacancy generation at high temperatures. This improvement led to higher performance, with the symmetric SOEC using an LSGM electrolyte and SFTCMM electrodes achieving a current density of 1.50 A cm−2 at 1.5 V and 800 °C, whereas the current density was 1.04 A cm−2 for the cell with SFM electrodes. Additionally, the symmetric SOEC with SFTCMM electrodes demonstrated 160 h of long-term stability during CO2 electrolysis. Therefore, the development of symmetric SOECs with high-entropy electrodes offers promising advantages by harnessing the unique stability and catalytic versatility of HEMs. Additionally, Pr0.5Ba0.5FeO3– δ (PBF)-based perovskites are robust electrode materials with outstanding electrochemical properties. Recently, Shao et al. [115] designed a Pr1/6La1/6Sm1/6Ba1/6Sr1/6Ca1/6FeO3– δ (PLSBSCF) electrode based on PBF (Fig. 8k). Compared with the PBF parent perovskite, PLSBSCF features abundant oxygen vacancies, good CO2 adsorption capacity, and rapid O2−/e− conduction, providing additional active sites for the CO2RR. Consequently, a single cell with PLSBSCF electrode achieved a current density of 1.89 A cm−2 at 800 °C and 1.5 V during direct CO2 electrolysis (Fig. 8l), which was 3.78 times greater than that of the PBF while maintaining thermal cycling stability for 62 h and operational durability for 220 h (Fig. 8m, n). In another study, Pr0.5Ba0.5Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2Cu0.2O3– δ [116] was subjected to in situ CO reduction to exsolve randomly distributed Fe-Co-Ni-Cu tetrameric alloy nanoparticles and generate additional oxygen vacancies. To assess the potential for metal formation, the authors calculated the change in ΔG for the chemical reactions involving Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, and Cu oxides with CO. The results showed that ΔG is negative for the reduction of Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu oxides at 800 °C, indicating that these four metals can spontaneously form in a CO atmosphere. The unique properties of HEMs offer significant potential to address the challenges associated with conventional fuel electrodes. Current research in HEM-based fuel electrodes highlights improved carbon resistance, thermal stability, and electrochemical performance. However, challenges include optimizing the high-entropy effect across diverse compositions and enhancing long-term stability in extreme operating conditions. Future research should explore multicomponent alloys with higher entropy configurations to balance stability with catalytic activity, aiming for fuel electrodes that can withstand broader fuel types and varying SOC environments. 5.2 HEMs as SOC electrolytes SOCs typically utilize solid oxide-based electrolytes, which can be categorized into two types: oxygen ion-conducting and proton-conducting electrolytes. Oxygen ion conductive electrolytes allow oxygen ions to move within the electrolyte, whereas proton conductive electrolytes promote the transport of protons and simultaneously block electron flow [9]. The solid electrolyte is a crucial component of SOCs and must meet several key requirements [40,117]: (i) excellent gas tightness; (ii) high ionic conductivity (exceeding 0.1 S cm−1) and low ohmic resistance (below 0.2 Ω cm2); (iii) purely ionic conductivity in both oxidizing and reducing environments; and (iv) strong chemical stability across a wide spectrum of oxygen partial pressures. The primary advantage of using HEOs as electrolytes in SOCs is their remarkable stability. HEOs can retain their structure and properties at high temperatures and in extreme environments, making them promising candidates for electrolyte materials in SOCs. This section explores the application of HEMs as electrolytes in both O-SOCs and P-SOCs. 5.2.1 Oxygen ion-conducting electrolytes Common oxygen ion conductor electrolytes include yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ), scandium-stabilized zirconia (ScSZ), lanthanum-doped cerium oxide (LDC), GDC, SDC, and LSGM. These materials are widely used for their excellent ionic conductivity and chemical stability at high temperatures. However, as SOFCs progress toward medium- and low-temperature operation, the demands for conductivity, thermomechanical stability, and chemical resistance of electrolyte materials have intensified. Consequently, advancing oxygen ion conductor electrolyte materials with enhanced performance has emerged as a key research focus. Among the stabilized zirconia variants, ScSZ and yttrium oxide-stabilized zirconia YSZ are notable for their high oxide ion conductivity. Each material has advantages and drawbacks. For example, ScSZ has the highest conductivity of all stabilized zirconias; however, it is prone to long-term aging under standard thermodynamic conditions. Conversely, YSZ is renowned for its excellent stability, although its overall conductivity is relatively low. Specifically, ScSZ experiences a ∼56% decrease in conductivity over 1,000 h at 1,000 °C, whereas YSZ shows a more moderate decline of ∼25% under the same conditions [118]. To address the limitations of using stabilized zirconia alone, Mathur et al. [119] explored a binary co-stabilized zirconia system with Yb3+ and Sc3+ co-doping (Seg-I), subsequently incorporating ternary co-doping (Seg-II) in the latter stages. For the composition (Sc2O3) x (Yb2O3)0.1– x (ZrO2)0.9, the sample with x = 0.08 demonstrated a conductivity of 0.087 S cm−1 for 150 h in air at 800 °C, with a 5.4% decay. The incorporation of various ternary co-dopants (M = MgO, In2O3, Sm2O3, or CaO) in Seg-II, with a composition of (M)0.005(Sc2O3)0.08(Yb2O3)0.02(ZrO2)0.895, significantly suppressed degradation. Among the various dopants, In-2Yb8SSZ exhibited the lowest degradation, at 3% over 270 h, but with a slight decrease in conductivity at 800 °C in air, reaching 0.08 S cm−1. The authors concluded that the ternary co-dopants partially replaced Zr4+, which suppressed the emergence of a substable t’ phase at elevated temperatures, thereby improving stability. Additionally, the quintuple-doped Ce1– x (Gd1/5Sm1/5Er1/5Y1/5Bi1/5) x O2– δ (GSEYB) system has also been reported [120]. When synthesized via a solid-phase reaction, this electrolyte had a relative density exceeding 96% after sintering at 1400 °C for 10 h. The GSEYB electrolyte with x = 0.25 demonstrated the greatest ionic conductivity at 800 °C (σt = 0.0445 S cm−1) and had the minimum activation energy of 0.79 eV. While the long-term stability of this sample was not tested, it can be hypothesized that quintuple doping may offer greater long-term stability than ternary doping, albeit with a slight reduction in ionic conductivity, potentially due to effects such as hysteretic diffusion in HEMs. 5.2.2 Proton-conducting electrolytes Proton transport (0.4–0.6 eV) [121] requires a lower activation energy than that of oxygen ions (0.7–1.2 eV) [122], enabling proton-conducting electrolytes to maintain high ionic conductivity and energy conversion efficiency at lower temperatures (400–700 °C). Researchers have long sought materials with high proton conductivity, leading to extensive studies on various oxide classes with fluorite, brown amphibole, apatite, perovskite, and other structures. Among these materials, perovskite (ABO3) has emerged as the most favorable material because of its high concentration and mobility of proton defects [123–125]. In 2020, Gazda et al. were pioneers in reporting proton conductivity values for HEPOs [60]. They synthesized several single-phase HEPOs, including BaZr0.2Sn0.2Ti0.2Hf0.2Ce0.2O3– δ , BaZr0.2Sn0.2Ti0.2Hf0.2Y0.2O3– δ (BZSTHY), BaZr1/7Sn1/7Ti1/7Hf1/7Ce1/7Nb1/7Y1/7O3– δ and BaZr0.15Sn0.15Ti0.15Hf0.15Ce0.15Nb0.15Y0.1O3– δ . Among these, BZSTHY demonstrated the highest proton conductivity in humidified air, reaching 6 × 10−5 S cm−1 at 600 °C. While this marked a significant advancement in the field, this conductivity remains considerably lower than that of traditional proton conductors because of its smaller grain size (40–500 nm) and lower relative density (72%), which impedes proton transport efficiency. This reduction in conductivity can be explained by the space charge layer theory. As grain size decreases, the number of grain boundaries increases, leading to the formation of space charge layers at these boundaries. These layers affect the local charge distribution, creating an electric field that can obstruct proton migration. Consequently, the increased ratio of grain boundaries in smaller grains results in more protons being blocked at these boundaries, thereby reducing overall proton conductivity [126,127]. In 2022, a novel proton conductor, the single-phase HEPO BaSn0.16Zr0.24Ce0.35Y0.1Yb0.1Dy0.05O3– δ (BSZCYYbD) [128], was applied for the first time in P-SOCs operating below 600 °C (Fig. 9 g). The proton conduction in BSZCYYbD was demonstrated by proton conductor isotope effects and hydration (Fig. 9h, i). The proton conductivity of BSZCYYbD was measured at 0.083 S cm−1 in humidified air (3% H2O) at 600 °C (Fig. 9j), and fuel electrode-supported single cell at 600 °C had a PPD of 318 mW cm−2. Doped zirconate-cerite compounds have been found to have both proton and oxygen ion conductivity, along with a significant affinity for water absorption or hydration [130,131]. Consequently, solid solutions based on BaCeO3 and BaZrO3, including BaZr0.1Ce0.7Y0.2O3– δ (BZCY) [132] and BaZr0.1Ce0.7Y0.1Yb0.1O3– δ (BZCYYb) [133], are currently the most widely used proton-conducting electrolytes. However, good chemical stability has not been achieved in environments containing H2O, CO2, or H2S [134,135]. Recently, a series of HEPOs have been reported as proton-conducting electrolytes, which are expected to address these stability issues. For example, the B-site of BaHf1/6Sn1/6Zr1/6Ce1/6Y1/6Yb1/6O3– δ (BHSZCYYb) binds six equimolar cations (Fig. 9a) [129]. When exposed to 30% CO2 at 600 °C, the short-term conductivity stability of BHSZCYYb over 90 h showed no significant degradation. (Fig. 9b). BHSZCYYb exhibited a conductivity of 0.092 S cm−1 at 600 °C under humid air conditions (Fig. 9c, d) and an activation energy of 0.49 eV. A P-SOEC using the BHSZCYYb electrolyte was prepared via microwave-assisted sintering. At 650 °C, the cell exhibited a PPD of 1.151 W cm−2 in FC mode and a current density of − 2.326 A cm−2 at 1.3 V in EC mode (Fig. 9e, f). This represents the highest performance for a P-SOEC with a HEPO electrolyte to date. For electrolytes, HEMs offer benefits in ionic conductivity and compatibility across cell components. The main challenges lie in achieving a balance between stability in reactive environments and high proton conductivity. Further studies could investigate high-entropy compositions that avoid phase degradation at lower sintering temperatures and achieve compatibility with NiO-based electrodes, thus reducing grain boundary resistance and enhancing overall electrolyte stability. 5.3 HEMs as SOC air electrodes As previously described in Section 2, the oxides with a ΔS config greater than 1.5 R are classified as HEOs, whereas those with ΔS config between 1.0 R and 1.5 R are categorized as medium-entropy oxides (MEOs). These oxides, with high configurational entropy, have been shown to significantly influence various properties, including chemical compatibility, TEC, electrical conductivity, oxygen surface exchange, bulk diffusion kinetics, electrochemical properties, and the long-term stability of SOC components [40,136]. This demonstrates their great potential in the field of SOCs. Therefore, this section introduces a series of medium- and high-entropy materials for SOC air electrodes, with a particular focus on new materials that have emerged in the last five years. The air electrode in SOCs plays a crucial role in catalyzing high-temperature electrochemical reactions. In O-SOCs operating in FC mode, oxygen molecules diffuse to the porous air electrode, adsorb at active sites, and undergo the ORR. The resulting oxygen ions migrate through a solid electrolyte (e.g., YSZ) to the fuel electrode, reacting with various fuels. This process’s efficiency is determined by the air electrode’s electrical conductivity, catalytic activity, and microstructure. In EC mode, the process reverses with the OER at the air electrode, driving oxygen production. Currently, SOC air electrodes are predominantly p-type conductors, where hole states are generated through oxygen vacancies or metal cation deficiencies to enhance conductivity. For O-SOCs, the air electrode materials primarily require O2−/e− double conductivity to expand the reaction-active zone and facilitate the ORR/OER efficiency. In P-SOCs, H+ replaces O2− as the main charge carrier in the electrolyte, and the fundamental working principles remain similar to those of O-SOCs. Since O2−, H+, and e− participate in the reaction at the air electrode simultaneously, which requires H+/O2−/e− triple conductivity for the air electrode of P-SOC [10]. Triple-conducting air electrodes increase active sites beyond the TPB, promoting enhanced reaction kinetics across the electrode surface [137]. To achieve efficient and stable electrochemical reactions, SOC air electrodes must meet the following criteria [138]: (i) high electronic conductivity (over 100 S cm−1 under operating conditions) and ionic conductivity; (ii) TEC values that match well with the electrolyte and interconnects; (iii) good chemical compatibility with the electrolyte and interconnects; (iv) sufficient porosity to allow rapid oxygen diffusion; (v) adequate stability under operating conditions during manufacturing and operation; (vi) high catalytic activity during the ORR/OER process; and (vii) cost-effectiveness. 5.3.1 A-site entropy engineering In a standard air electrode design, the A-site of the ABO3-type perovskite structure is stabilized by a larger alkaline earth metal, which provides a structural framework, whereas the B-site transition metal offers a redox pair essential for catalytic activity. To ensure phase and structural stability against variations in gas composition and temperature, as well as to increase electronic and ionic conductivities, dopants are typically introduced at the A-site or B-site [28]. Although increasing the configurational entropy at the B-site improves the structural stability of the electrode material, it often comes at the expense of power output, as the electrocatalytic activity is compromised by the occupation of multiple metal elements at the B-site [137]. To counter this, A-site entropy engineering, which has been shown to significantly enhance the ion conductivity and overall electrochemical performance of air electrodes, has been developed for HEPOs. An A-site high-entropy SOC air electrode was first reported by Yang et al. [139]. In 2020, La0.2Pr0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Sr0.2MnO3– δ (HE-LSM) was designed on the basis of an electron-conducting La0.8Sr0.2MnO3– δ perovskite. The lattice distortion induced by the high dispersion of A-site cations restricted the Sr transport rate, effectively preventing Sr segregation over extended operation. However, owing to the fewer ionic conductivity of Mn-based perovskites, the single cell utilizing the NiO-YSZ|YSZ|GDC|HE-LSM structure achieved a PPD of only 801 mW cm−2 at 800 °C. In 2022, Shao et al. [137] prepared a Co-based A-site high-entropy oxide, Pr1/6La1/6Nd1/6Ba1/6Sr1/6Ca1/6CoO3– δ (PLNBSCC), using the sol–gel method. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) imaging and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping confirmed the uniform distribution of the elements (Fig. 10 a). Characterization of O2− conductivity, conductivity under humid air conditions, and infrared spectroscopy results indicates that PLNBSCC has H+/O2−/e− triple conductivity characteristics. High conductivity is crucial for commercial air electrode applications. The conductivity of PLNBSCC oxides in dry air ranges from 950 to 2040 S cm−1 within the temperature range of 300–800 °C. Furthermore, the single cell with a PLNBSCC air electrode outperformed other cells using famous air electrode materials, such as BaCo0.4Fe0.4Zr0.1Y0.1O3– δ (BCFZY) and Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3– δ (BSCF) (Fig. 10b). With a thinner electrolyte layer (6.5 μm), the PPD of the Ni-BZCYYb|BZCYYb|PLNBSCC single cell increased to 1.21 W cm−2 at 600 °C, marking one of the highest recorded electrochemical performances. (Fig. 10c). This study opens new possibilities for developing high-performance air electrodes for P-SOCs. Recently, Chen et al. [140] synthesized Pr0.2Ba0.2Sr0.2La0.2Ca0.2CoO3– δ (PBSLCC) as an air electrode for P-SOCs via the sol–gel method and tested its performance in EC mode. X-ray diffraction (XRD) combined with Rietveld refinement revealed that PBSLCC has a cubic single-phase structure belonging to the Pm-3m space group. The single cell with a Ni-BZCYYb|BZCYYb|PBSLCC configuration exhibited a PPD of 1.51 W cm−2 in FC mode at 650 °C and a current density of −2.68 A cm−2 at 1.3 V in EC mode. (Fig. 10d, e). Additionally, these cells demonstrated good operational endurance, exceeding 270 h in FC mode and 500 h in EC mode (Fig. 10f, g). The high performance and stability of SOCs in reverse mode enable them to efficiently switch between power generation and energy storage, making them ideal for integration with renewable sources such as solar and wind. In addition, PBSLCC electrodes for O-SOCs also achieved strong performance [141]. The single cell with PBSLCC electrode supported by the LSGM electrolyte showed good performance at 800 °C, exhibiting a PPD of 1.2 W cm−2 in FC mode and a current density of −1.1 A cm−2 in EC mode at 1.3 V. The application of the bulk-phase oxygen p-band-center model confirmed that entropy modulation at the A-site enhanced the surface exchange coefficient (k chem) and bulk diffusion coefficient (D chem), leading to higher oxygen reactivity in PBSLCC compared to binary and ternary perovskites. During the operation of SOCs, the air electrode is exposed to high temperatures and an atmosphere of air or oxygen, which may contain impurities such as CO2. CO2 can react with the electrode material to form carbonates, leading to degradation of material properties, loss of electrical conductivity, and impaired mechanical stability [142,143]. Therefore, it is crucial for air electrode materials to exhibit strong resistance to CO2 poisoning to ensure the high efficiency and long operational lifetime of SOCs. He et al. introduced additional calcium doping into the equimolar PBSLCC structure [141] to create an A-site calcium-rich high-entropy electrode, Pr0.1875Ba0.1875Sr0.1875La0.1875Ca0.25CoO3– δ (PBSLC25C) [144]. The PBSLC25C electrode demonstrated excellent regenerative R p stability (Fig. 11 a) and was tested for over 400 h with 1%, 5%, and 10% CO2 in air, outperforming the PrBa0.8Sr0.2Co2O6– δ (PBSC) electrode. Additionally, the single cells with a Ni-YSZ|YSZ|PBSLC25C configuration presented PPDs of 1.21, 1.14, 1.04, and 0.77 W cm−2 at 750 °C in 0%, 1%, 5%, and 10% CO2 in air, respectively (Fig. 11b). After 50 h of exposure to 10% CO2 in air at 750 °C, the PBSLC25C electrode presented significantly fewer carbonates on its surface than did the PBSC electrode (Fig. 11c, d), which was attributed to the lower CO2 adsorption energy on the PBSLC25C electrode (−0.55 eV) than on the PBSC electrode (−0.76 eV) (Fig. 11e). These findings indicate that HEOs have great potential for mitigating CO2 poisoning. Alkaline earth metal ions (e.g., Ba2+, Sr2+, and Ca2+) are commonly incorporated into the A-site of perovskite-type oxides because of their larger ionic radii and lower oxidation states, which help increase the number of oxygen vacancies and enhance the ORR kinetics [145]. Nevertheless, in practice, the accumulation or segregation of these elements at the electrode surface or electrode–electrolyte interface—driven by electrostatic forces and elastic energy minimization—has been widely reported. This segregation changes the chemical composition of the electrode material, leading to reduced electrocatalytic activity and decreased lifespan [146]. Additionally, the common use of metal alloy connectors in SOCs, which often contain chromium to improve oxidation and corrosion resistance through the formation of a protective Cr2O3 layer, further exacerbates this issue (Fig. 12 a). Isolated Sr2+ or Ba2+ ions act as nucleation sites and readily react with highly volatile chromium species (e.g., CrO3 and CrO2(OH)2) generated from the Cr2O3 layer of the connectors, forming inert solid phases such as SrCrO4, BaCrO4, and Cr2O3. These deposits accumulate on the electrode surface or at the electrode–electrolyte interface, potentially hindering oxygen adsorption and dissociation, obstructing electron conduction, and blocking gas diffusion channels in the air electrode, resulting in significant performance degradation (i.e., Cr poisoning). Therefore, air electrode materials must demonstrate strong resistance to Cr poisoning to ensure the optimal performance and durability of SOCs. Recently, the HEO Pr0.2Sm0.2Nd0.2Gd0.2La0.2BaCo2O5+ δ (PSNGLBC) was reported as a chromium-resistant air electrode for SOCs by Chen et al. [147]. After 100 h of exposure to a Cr-containing atmosphere in humid air at 700 °C, PSNGLBC particles demonstrated significantly lower accumulations of Cr2O3 and BaCrO4 contaminants than did PBC particles. Additionally, the single cell was operated for 115 h in dry air and 164 h in wet air at 0.5 A cm−2 under actual operating conditions with a Cr-containing atmosphere. Compared with the low-entropy La0.6Sr0.4Co0.2Fe0.8O3– δ (LSCF) and PBC electrodes, the high-entropy PSNGLBC electrode exhibited superior activity and stability when exposed to a Cr atmosphere in both dry and wet air. This improvement could be attributed to the high-entropy effect and the retarded diffusion effect, which together fostered the development of a stable crystalline morphology and phase structure while also suppressing Ba segregation. Furthermore, when used as the air electrode in fuel electrode-supported single cell, the PSNGLBC electrode reached a high PPD of 2.03 W cm−2 at 800 °C and exhibited a degradation rate of 0.07% per hour over 142 h of operational testing (Fig. 12b, c). A series of new HEOs have been reported as air electrode materials for SOCs [148]. Even slight changes in the A-site elements, as little as 10% of the total cations, can significantly impact the overall performance. Among these materials, (La0.2Sr0.2Pr0.2Y0.2Ba0.2)Co0.2Fe0.8O3– δ exhibits excellent chromium resistance, with a degradation rate of only 0.25% per kilohour over a 41-day operational period in a Cr atmosphere, representing one of the longest stabilities achieved thus far in a Cr atmosphere. A mix of oxygen ions and electronic conductivity are critical for ensuring the efficient, low-temperature operation of air electrode materials in SOFCs. Conventional iron-based perovskite air electrodes often suffered from low electronic and oxygen ion conductivity, leading to insufficient ORR activity. To address this, Han et al. et al. [149] synthesized A-site high-entropy La0.2Pr0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Gd0.2BaFe2O5+ δ (LPNSGBF) oxides, which are based on cobalt-free PrBaFe2O5+ δ (PBF) double perovskite materials, as high-catalytic-activity and chromium-resistant air electrodes for SOFCs. An impedance response analysis, as shown in Fig. 12(d), indicated that the LPNSGBF half-cells exhibited less performance degradation than the PBF half-cells did. Both PBF and LPNSGBF were treated with Cr at 800 °C for 24 h. The Raman profiles of the electrode surfaces prior to and following treatment are shown in Fig. 12(e, f). A distinct vibrational peak of CrO4 2− appeared at a Raman shift of approximately 860 cm−1 in the Cr-treated PBF sample, whereas the Cr-treated LPNSGBF sample showed only a minimal change in peak intensity at 860 cm−1. The authors attributed the Cr poisoning to the Ba polarization reaction on the perovskite surface, where Ba cations are enriched first on the surface to form insulating phases (e.g., BaO and BaCO3). These Ba species can then react with gaseous CrO3 to form BaCrO4, further affecting the catalytic active sites of the Fe cations in the electrode. The reduced Ba surface enrichment in LPNSGBF suggests that the high-entropy effect effectively inhibits Ba polarization, thereby enhancing the Cr tolerance of the electrode. Table 3 presents the long-term stability of typical HEMs and conventional materials under both normal and extreme conditions. It is evident that HEMs demonstrate superior stability under harsh operating conditions, making them excellent candidates for future industrial applications. Additionally, various other HEOs have demonstrated excellent stability as air electrodes for SOCs. Notable examples include Co/Fe based simple perovskites such as (La0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Sr0.2Ba0.2)Co0.2Fe0.8O3 [150], (La0.2Nd0.2Gd0.2Sr0.2Ba0.2)Co0.2Fe0.8O3– δ [151], La0.2Pr0.2Ba0.2Sr0.2Ca0.2CoO3 [152], (Pr0.2Sr0.2La0.2Ba0.2Ca0.2)Co0.2Fe0.8O3– δ and (Pr0.2Sr0.2La0.2Ba0.2Nd0.2)Co0.2Fe0.8O3– δ [153], double perovskite such as Pr0.4La0.4Ba0.4Sr0.4Ca0.4Fe2O5+ δ [154], (La, Pr, Nd, Sm, Gd)BaCo2O5+ δ [155], (La0.2Pr0.2Sm0.2Gd0.2Nd0.2)Ba0.5Sr0.5Co1.5Fe0.5O5 [156], and R-P type perovskite (La0.2Pr0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Gd0.2)2CuO4 [157]. However, the catalytic activity and stability of electrodes are not solely dependent on high configurational entropy but are also significantly influenced by the doping elements. For example, Pr1/2Ca1/2CoO3– δ (PCC, ΔS config = 0.693 R), Pr1/2Ba1/4Ca1/4CoO3– δ (PBCC, ΔS config = 1.040 R), Pr1/2Ba1/6Sr1/6Ca1/6CoO3– δ (PBSCC, ΔS config = 1.242 R), Pr1/2Ba1/8Sr1/8Cs1/8Ca1/8CoO3– δ (PBSCCC, ΔS config = 1.386 R), and Pr1/2Ba1/10Sr1/10Cs1/10Ca1/10Na1/10CoO3– δ (PBSCCNC, ΔS config = 1.498 R) were designed as entropy-ascending air electrodes for SOCs [158]. However, at 700 °C in ambient air, the area-specific resistance (ASR) initially decreases and then increases with increasing configurational entropy, with the PBSCC displaying the lowest ASR (0.037 Ω 2). This trend suggests that the chemical properties of the selected elements, such as ionic radius and valence, also play crucial roles in entropy regulation. 5.3.2 B-site entropy engineering In 2020, Dabrowa et al. first reported the use of HEMs as air electrode materials for SOCs [159]. Since then, HEMs have been increasingly explored as components in various SOCs. They investigated a range of B-site entropy-engineered perovskite-type oxides La1– x Sr x (Co, Cr, Fe, Mn, Ni)O3– δ (x = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, and 0.5). Among these materials, La0.7Sr0.3(Co, Cr, Fe, Mn, Ni)O3– δ has strong potential as an air electrode material for SOCs. This work represents a major milestone in applying HEMs to the SOC field. It is widely recognized that Sr segregation is a major factor contributing to the reduced long-term stability of SOCs [145,146,160]. In 2021, a medium-entropy perovskite, Sr(FeαTiβCoγMnζ)O3– δ (SFTCM, α + β + γ + ζ = 1), was developed featuring four transition metals at the B-site to retain catalytic activity while reducing Sr segregation [161]. Specifically, SrFe0.25Ti0.25Co0.25Mn0.25O3– δ (SFTCM25, ΔS config = 1.39 R), with a relatively high ΔS config, has a TEC of 16.96 × 10−6 K−1 in the 50–900 °C range, which is lower than that of SrFe0.5Ti0.2Co0.2Mn0.1O3– δ (SFTCM5221, ΔS config = 1.22 R), which has a TEC of 20.05 × 10−6 K−1 (Fig. 13 a). Although high configurational entropy reduces the total conductivity and the oxygen surface exchange rate, it promotes oxygen ion migration within the lattice. Additionally, high entropy effectively inhibits surface Sr segregation and enhances structural stability (Fig. 13b, c). LSGM-supported single cells with SFTCM5221 and SFTCM25 air electrodes achieved PPDs of 1.03 and 0.85 W cm−2 at 800 °C, respectively. Recently, Gao et al. [162] synthesized a Sr-deficient medium-entropy air electrode, Sr1-xCo0.5Fe0.2Ti0.1Ta0.1Nb0.1O3– δ (S1– x CFTTN), which effectively suppresses Sr segregation (Fig. 13d). An appropriate Sr deficiency in S0.95CFTTN resulted in the highest conductivity and the fastest oxygen exchange kinetics among the samples tested, with a R p of 0.024 Ω cm2 at 700 °C, which was lower than the 0.037 Ω cm2 of the SCFTTN electrode. A single cell with the Ni-YSZ|YSZ|GDC|S0.95CFTTN structure exhibited a higher PPD of 1153.5 mW cm−2 at 800 °C (Fig. 13e, f) and maintained stability for over 100 h in a Cr-containing atmosphere (Fig. 13h). The S0.95CFTTN electrode also demonstrated significantly improved Cr tolerance due to the presence of Sr defects, which reduced the degree of Sr segregation on the electrode surface, minimizing the formation of SrCrO4 (Fig. 13i, j). Gao et al. previously investigated undefected SrCo0.5Fe0.2Ti0.1Ta0.1Nb0.1O3– δ (SCFTTN52111) oxide, which also exhibited some Cr tolerance [163]. In the presence of volatile Cr species, large amounts of SrCrO4 and Co3O4 secondary phases were detected on the SrCo0.9Ta0.1O3– δ (SCT91) parent electrode, whereas only trace byproducts were observed on SCFTTN52111. The enhanced Cr resistance is closely related to the improved structural stability and reduced surface Sr segregation achieved through medium-entropy engineering, as the gaseous Cr preferentially deposits on Sr rather than on Co3O4 segregation (Fig. 13g). Additionally, SCFTTN52111 also exhibited favorable CO2 tolerance [164]. Reducing the Sr doping level is another effective strategy for suppressing Sr segregation and improving stability. Li et al. [165] synthesized a MEO air electrode, La0.7Sr0.3Co0.25Fe0.25Ni0.25Mn0.25O3– δ (LSCFNM73), where the Sr content at the A-site was reduced to 30%. The assembled NiO-YSZ|YSZ|GDC|LSCFNM73-GDC single cell demonstrated a PPD of 1088 mW cm−2 at 800 °C, with good stability at 750 °C for 120 h under a constant voltage of 0.75 V, and maintained performance over 10 thermal cycles between 750 °C and 400 °C. In conclusion, entropy engineering strategy provides a promising approach to reduce strontium segregation and enhance electrode stability. Notably, in 2022, BaCo0.2Fe0.2Zr0.2Sn0.2Pr0.2O3– δ (BCFZSP) high-entropy oxide was first reported as an air electrode for P-SOCs by Wang et al. [166]. This material exhibits H+/O2−/e− triple conductivity within single-phase perovskite, where proton conductivity is critical for P-SOC air electrode materials. The triple conduction mechanism extends the electrochemically active sites across the entire surface of the air electrode, thereby enhancing the kinetics of the ORR and OER. Based on the typical proton formation mechanism, oxygen vacancies are considered a prerequisite for proton formation [10]. The authors describe the hydration reaction process on the air electrode, where water molecules are adsorbed on the electrode surface in the EC mode. This adsorption relies on the hydration reaction between oxygen vacancies and water molecules, resulting in the formation of proton defects (Fig. 14 a, b). In the FC mode, water produced by the interaction of proton defects with lattice oxygen exits through the lattice gap (Fig. 14b, c). Consequently, the interaction between H2O and oxygen vacancies significantly contributes to the electrochemical properties of P-SOCs. Thermogravimetric analysis was conducted on the samples to assess their hydration capacity (Fig. 14d–f). The samples were first heated from room temperature to 900 °C to create oxygen vacancies and then cooled under dry and humid air (p(H2O) = 10% atm) to examine the adsorption behavior of oxygen and H2O (Fig. 14d). The results showed that BCFZSP exhibited superior hydration/dehydration capabilities (Fig. 14d, f) and higher proton conductivity (Fig. 14e) than classical BCFZY materials. The prepared P-SOCs with BCFZSP air electrodes achieved a PPD of 680 W cm−2 in FC mode at 600 °C and a current density of 0.92 A cm−2 in EC mode at an applied voltage of 1.3 V. The P-SOCs demonstrated high stability over 120 h of reversible switching between FC and EC modes. Yang et al. also designed a B-site HEPO BaCo0.2Zn0.2Ga0.2Zr0.2Y0.2O3– δ (BCX) based on BaCoO3– δ (BC) for air electrodes of P-SOCs [167]. The TEC of BCX was as low as 12.75 × 10−6 K−1, whereas that of the BC parent was 18.69 × 10−6 K−1. By reducing the Co content and employing entropy engineering, the issues of a high TEC and incompatibility of Co based perovskite air electrodes with electrolyte TECs can be effectively resolved. The BCX at 600 °C was accompanied by a R p of approximately 0.69 Ω cm2. The cells with BCX electrode exhibited long-term stability for more than 100 h. To further enhance the performance, the authors designed Ba0.95K0.05Co0.2Zn0.2Ga0.2Zr0.2Y0.2O3– δ (BKCX) through a low Lewis acid strength cation (K+)-doping strategy [168]. Theoretically, doping with low Lewis acid strength cations can increase the alkalinity of the oxide, enhance water adsorption and optimize the hydration reaction, thereby increasing the concentration of proton defects [169,170]. In K2NiF4-type oxides, the B-site is occupied by transition metal ions. The introduction of high entropy alters the oxidation state and ionic radius of these metal ions, making them more prone to metal–oxygen bond breakage. This generates additional oxygen vacancies, which accelerate the transport of oxygen ions and protons, thereby improving the electrocatalytic activity of the air electrode [171]. Recently, the B-site K2NiF4-type Ruddlesden-Popper phase HEO La1.2Sr0.8Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2Cu0.2O4+ δ (LSMFCNC) was reported as air electrode material for SOCs [172]. XPS analysis revealed that the binding energies of La3+ and Ni2+/Ni3+ in LSMFCNC are lower than those in La1.2Sr0.8NiO4+ δ (LSNO). Consequently, the LaOLa and NiONi bonds in LSMFCNC are more readily broken, resulting in the formation of additional oxygen vacancies (Fig. 14g), which in turn increases the proton/oxygen diffusion rate and ORR activity. The improved oxygen adsorption capacity, superior charge transfer ability, and excellent oxygen ion diffusion collectively accelerated the oxygen ion transport process within the bulk phase of the LSMFCNCs (Fig. 14j, k). The single cell with a NiO-BZCY|AFL|BZCY|LSMFCNC structure achieved a PPD of 1126 mW cm−2 at 600 °C, corresponding to an R p of 0.179 Ω cm2. This represents relatively high performance achievable with high entropy in the current B-site configuration (Fig. 14h, i). 5.3.3 A, B-site co-entropy engineering For ceramic materials, the synthesis process significantly influences key factors such as powder morphology, elemental distribution, particle size, and processability. It is often necessary to adjust these properties to suit the specific demands of the target application. Schweidler et al. synthesized A, B-site co-entropy engineered HEOs (Gd0.2Sr0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Y0.2)(Co0.2Cr0.2Fe0.2Mn0.2Ni0.2)O3 (HEO-Sr) via mechanochemical synthesis (ball milling, BM) and a modified Pechini method (PM), respectively [173]. HAADF imaging and EDX revealed that in Pechini-synthesized HEO-Sr, the segregation of Sr and Cr occurred at the same locations (Fig. 15 a). In contrast, the elements in the ball-milled powder were uniformly distributed (Fig. 15b). HEO-Sr synthesized via the Pechini method exhibited a network of loosely connected point-shaped structures, whereas the BM-prepared HEO-Sr showed dense agglomerates (Fig. 15c, d). Although ball milling produced a pure perovskite phase, the resulting powder morphology was unsuitable for further processing and sintering, limiting its integration into electrochemical devices. In contrast, the Pechini method yielded a more uniform particle size distribution, enhancing powder processability. The comparison of these methods not only highlights the ability to customize the elemental composition of HEMs but also underscores the potential for optimizing synthesis techniques to overcome the limitations of conventional ceramics. A, B-site co-entropy engineering of perovskite materials can achieve a ΔS config of 2.0 R or higher. However, the number of A, B-site co-entropy engineering HEOs for SOCs remains limited. This may be because increasing entropy does not necessarily lead to continuous performance improvements. For example, Chen et al. [158] investigated a series of HEO air electrodes with varying entropy values, finding that the ASR of PBCC (ΔS config = 1.242 R) was lower than that of PBSCCNC (ΔS config = 1.498 R). Yang et al. [174] synthesized La0.2Pr0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Ba0.1Sr0.1Co0.2Fe0.6Ni0.1Cu0.1O3– δ (HEP) with a cubic perovskite single-phase structure (Fig. 15e) via a simple one-pot combustion method.
