SEM analysis revealed that the HEP powder had uniform particle distribution and high porosity. At 800 °C, HEP demonstrated a R p of 0.3 Ω cm2 on a symmetric cell with a YSZ electrolyte, which is half that of a La0.8Sr0.2FeO3– δ (LSF) electrode (0.6 Ω cm2) under the same conditions. Additionally, a single cell with a Ni-YSZ|YSZ|GDC|HEP structure achieved a PPD of 714 mW cm−2 at 800 °C (Fig. 15f). These findings suggest that A, B-site co-entropy engineering has potential for improving the performance of SOC air electrodes. Comparing the performance improvements of A-site, B-site, and A, B co-entropy engineering strategies reveals critical differences in catalytic activity and stability, facilitating more targeted high-entropy material designs (Table 4 and Table 5 ). Among these strategies, A-site entropy engineering generally achieves the highest catalytic performance when applied as SOC air electrode materials. This advantage is attributed to increased configurational entropy at the A-site, which stabilizes the structure without significantly occupying or diluting the active metal sites needed for catalytic reactions [137]. In contrast, B-site entropy engineering tends to prioritize properties like ionic conductivity and hydration capacity, often enhancing the material’s resistance to phase separation and degradation at high temperatures [166]. A, B co-entropy strategies aim to balance these effects; however, current findings indicate that A, B co-entropy materials often do not surpass A-site-only entropy-engineered materials in catalytic efficiency. Therefore, based on current data, A-site entropy-engineered materials present the most promising approach for SOC air electrodes by effectively balancing activity and stability. Meanwhile, B-site entropy-engineered materials, with favorable ionic conductivity and degradation resistance, could be excellent candidates for SOC electrolytes. Given the limited studies on A, B co-entropy materials, further exploration of their physicochemical performance as SOC air electrodes remains necessary. 5.4 HEMs as SOC interconnects In practical SOC applications, several cells are typically stacked in series to achieve the desired voltage output, necessitating the use of interconnects to connect multiple single cells, as illustrated in Fig. 16 (a). Interconnects establish an electrical link between the air electrode of one cell and the fuel electrode of the neighboring cell in a SOC stack. They also act as a physical barrier, separating the reducing atmosphere at the fuel electrode from the oxidizing atmosphere at the air electrode. Consequently, the selection criteria for interconnect materials are more rigorous and demanding than those for other cell components [138]. The requirements for interconnecting materials include [175–177]: (i) high electrical conductivity with an ASR below 0.1 Ω 2; (ii) structural, microstructural, chemical, and phase stability at operating temperatures of 800–1000 °C; (iii) outstanding gas toughness or impermeability to oxygen and hydrogen; (iv) a TEC (∼10.5 × 10−6 K−1) compatible with electrode and electrolyte materials; (v) chemical inertness to adjacent components; (vi) excellent resistance to oxidation, vulcanization, and carbonization; (vii) sufficient mechanical strength and high creep resistance to prevent fracture under operational stress; (viii) cost-effectiveness; and (ix) ease of fabrication and forming. The interconnect materials currently used for SOCs fall into two main categories: ceramics and metal alloys. Lanthanum chromate (LaCrO3)-based perovskites are the most commonly used ceramic interconnects. However, the electrical conductivity of ceramics decreases sharply below 800 °C, making them unsuitable for low- to medium-temperature SOCs. One of the key challenges in the large-scale production of LaCrO3-doped ceramic interconnects is their poor sintering behavior in air, attributed to the volatility of Cr(VI), which makes achieving adequate gas tightness difficult. Additionally, the high oxygen diffusivity in reducing atmospheres increases oxygen transport through interconnects, potentially degrading fuel cell performance. In contrast, metal interconnects present advantages such as easier manufacturing, reduced costs, improved mechanical strength, and enhanced electrical and thermal conductivity [175,178]. Cr-based alloys, particularly Ducrolloy (Cr-5Fe-1Y2O3), represent a promising alternative to ceramic interconnects because of their superior electrical conductivity [179]. Among these alloys, those with 17–25% chromium, such as ferritic stainless steels, are preferred for their enhanced processability and cost-effectiveness, as well as their compatibility with the body-centered cubic structure of SOC components. In contrast, Ni-Cr-based alloys, while offering excellent oxidation resistance and high electrical conductivity, are limited by their excessively high TECs. Although Cr-containing alloys are commonly studied for their ability to interconnect with metals because of their high conductivity, they encounter significant issues in high-oxygen environments. The formation of volatile Cr compounds, such as Cr(VI) oxides and hydroxyl oxides, leads to the development of solid precipitates such as Cr2O3 and SrCrO4 at the TPB of the air electrode. These precipitates hinder oxygen reduction reactions and thus degrade the overall electrochemical performance of the electrode (Fig. 16b). To address these challenges, metal connectors are frequently coated with conductive ceramics to improve surface stability [180]. Owing to their high conductivity, perovskite and spinel materials are considered primary candidates for diffusion barrier layers. Perovskite coatings face challenges in achieving good densification and adhesion. In contrast, spinel coatings are more easily prepared, either through direct deposition of spinel oxides or by thermal conversion from alloy coatings. Studies have demonstrated that appropriate compositional modifications can achieve the desired conductivity and TEC for spinel coatings. Zhao et al. [181] deposited a high-entropy alloy coating of FeCoNiMnCu in an equimolar ratio on the surface of SUS 430 steel via magnetron sputtering. The coated steel surface exhibited a cauliflower-like texture, with the coating being approximately 4 µm thick and well bonded to the steel substrate (Fig. 16c, d). After exposure to air at 800 °C for one week, the alloy coating transformed into a high-entropy spinel coating, (Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu)3O4, with a thin layer of CuO on the outer surface, increasing the coating thickness to 9 µm (Fig. 16e, f). After 10 weeks, a homogeneous (Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu)3O4 coating formed via a solid-phase reaction, resulting in the creation of a protective Cr2O3 layer at the interface between the substrate and the spinel coating. This process increased the coating thickness to 12 µm, with a surface Cr concentration of only 4.34% (Fig. 16g, h). The (Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu)3O4 spinel coating effectively inhibited the growth of the Cr2O3 layer within the coating and suppressed the outward diffusion of Cr during prolonged exposure. The ASR values measured at 800 °C after 1, 5, and 10 weeks of oxidation were 8.21, 7.67, and 6.59 mΩ cm2, respectively, which were lower than those of the FeCoCrNiMn high-entropy alloy prepared by Sahane et al. via the vacuum arc melting method (800 °C, 14 mΩ cm2) [182]. Additionally, the CuMnNiFeCo alloy prepared by Yu et al. via screen printing on ZMG 232 L metal interconnections had an ASR of 10.84 mΩ cm2 and a degradation rate of 1.7 mΩ cm2/1000 h after thermal conversion [183]. The reduction in ASR is attributed to the transformation of the (Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu)3O4/CuO structure into a homogeneous (Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu)3O4 spinel layer. Importantly, ASR is influenced by the thermally grown oxide (TGO) formed during oxidation rather than the resistivity of HEAs [182]. At 600 °C, the scaled ASR is 17 mΩ cm2, which is well below the acceptable ASR limit of 0.1 Ω 2. The high-entropy spinel-coated (Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu)3O4 material demonstrates promising properties for use in steel interconnects. HEMs for interconnects exhibit potential for higher electrical conductivity and stability at varying operating temperatures. Challenges include balancing TEC for compatibility with other SOC components and enhancing phase stability under repeated thermal cycling. Prospective research should focus on designing high-entropy perovskites or spinels with optimized TEC, reduced phase migration, and improved oxidation resistance, paving the way for reliable, long-term interconnect materials. 6 Conclusions and perspectives HEMs have emerged as highly versatile candidates for next-generation SOC components because of their remarkable ability to stabilize multiphase structures through entropy-driven mechanisms. This review highlights the transformative role HEMs can play in addressing the long-standing challenges of SOCs, such as improving the thermal, mechanical, and chemical stability of electrodes and electrolytes under harsh operating conditions. HEMs, particularly HEOs and HEAs, exhibit enhanced electrochemical properties, including increased ionic and electronic conductivity, resistance to degradation, and better compatibility between different cell components, owing to their configurational entropy and complex multicomponent compositions. Moreover, the unique capacity of HEMs to maintain single-phase structures at high temperatures has shown promise in extending the operational lifespan of SOCs. This review also underscores the importance of the synthesis method in determining the microstructure and performance of a material. Techniques such as mechanochemical synthesis, spark plasma sintering, and co-precipitation have proven effective in fine-tuning the composition and phase stability of HEMs. However, the complex interplay between configurational entropy, phase evolution, and the defect chemistry of HEMs requires further investigation. Although progress has been made, the current understanding of how compositional diversity affects electrochemical performance, phase stability, and long-term durability remains limited. Based on these conclusions, several perspectives for future research are proposed. (a) Fuel electrodes: HEAs present a significant advantage as fuel electrodes due to their resistance to carbon deposition, which is a major issue in hydrocarbon-fueled SOCs. This resistance stems from the unique effects of configurational entropy, which suppresses carbon formation and accumulation. Current research predominantly focuses on HEAs composed of four or five elements, but expanding this research to more complex alloys (such as those containing seven or even eleven elements) could lead to further improvements in stability and performance, particularly under extreme conditions. In SOECs, surface-modified alloy electrodes have demonstrated enhanced performance following reduction treatments, but the agglomeration of alloy nanoparticles over time reduces the number of active sites and hinders long-term stability. Preventing this agglomeration, potentially through the integration of perovskite materials that maintain single-phase stability without reduction treatment, could offer a solution. The high-entropy effect can enhance long-term durability, making this a key area for future fuel electrode design. (b) Electrolytes: Electrolytes are essential to SOCs. However, the development of P-SOC electrolytes faces significant challenges, particularly in terms of balancing proton conductivity, chemical stability, and compatibility with other cell components. The most widely studied electrolytes, BaZr x Y1– x O3 (BZY) and BaCe x Y1– x O3 (BCY), present a trade-off: BZY has excellent chemical stability in CO2− and moisture-rich environments but suffers from low proton conductivity, whereas BCY has high proton conductivity but is chemically unstable under similar conditions. A critical issue during the co-sintering process is the high temperature (1400–1600 °C) required for densification, which results in interdiffusion between the electrolyte and Ni based fuel electrode, leading to phase decomposition and reduced conductivity. Balancing proton conductivity while preventing the formation of secondary phases, such as Y2O3 and BaY2NiO5, remains a key challenge. HEMs offer promising solutions to these challenges. The configurational entropy inherent in multielement systems can stabilize more phases, allowing the synthesis of electrolytes that combine the chemical stability of BZY with the proton conductivity of BCY. Furthermore, the multicomponent nature of high-entropy electrolytes reduces grain boundary resistance, enhances proton mobility, and suppresses the formation of unwanted phases during sintering. HEMs also offer the potential for reduced sintering temperatures, which can minimize detrimental interactions with NiO and improve long-term electrolyte stability. Future research should focus on optimizing high-entropy electrolyte compositions to achieve an ideal balance between conductivity and stability while also improving their mechanical and thermal properties for more durable P-SOC operation. (c) Air electrodes: Despite recent advancements in high-entropy air electrode materials, long-term stability testing remains limited, with most tests lasting between 100 and 200 h, and even shorter durations under extreme conditions such as chromium-containing atmospheres. This is significantly below the several thousand hours required for commercial SOC applications. Bridging this gap is crucial for ensuring long-term viability in real-world environments. Additionally, B-site entropy engineering has shown promise in improving the structural stability of perovskite electrodes, but this often comes at the cost of catalytic activity, as transition metal sites are occupied by introduced elements. Consequently, A-site entropy engineering should be prioritized, as current evidence suggests that A-site high-entropy air electrodes outperform B-site configurations. However, the mechanisms behind these performance improvements—either due to specific elemental contributions or the increase in configurational entropy—are not fully understood and require further exploration. Elucidating these factors will be key to optimizing the design of future high-entropy air electrodes. (d) Interconnects: Interconnecting materials play crucial roles in the efficiency and durability of SOC stacks. Spinel-based materials currently outperform perovskites because of their higher electrical conductivity, ranging from 100 to 500 S cm−1, than the 10 to 100 S cm−1 typical of perovskites. However, entropy engineering of perovskite structures has the potential to significantly increase their conductivity, reaching up to 1000 to 2000 S cm−1. This opens new opportunities for high-entropy perovskites to serve as competitive interconnect materials in SOCs, provided that they can maintain structural integrity across a range of thermal and electrochemical conditions. Further research should focus on developing high-entropy perovskites with optimized electrical and thermal properties for interconnect applications. Additionally, understanding the impact of configurational entropy on the TEC is critical, as TEC compatibility with other SOC components is essential to prevent mechanical failure during operation. (e) Artificial intelligence in high-entropy material design: Artificial intelligence (AI), including machine learning (ML), offers transformative potential to accelerate the discovery and optimization of HEMs. AI enables rapid screening of candidate materials, predicting essential properties such as phase stability, conductivity, and mechanical strength—critical factors for SOC applications. By building accurate ML models, researchers can swiftly identify HEAs and HEOs with optimal electrochemical performance and operational stability. AI also facilitates comprehensive performance assessments, encompassing multi-dimensional criteria such as conductivity, durability, and thermal compatibility. Algorithms like neural networks, random forests, and support vector machines provide high predictive power for complex behaviors and achieve greater accuracy with extensive datasets from experiments and theoretical models. Multi-objective optimization frameworks further aid in identifying compositions that balance multiple properties, a vital approach for materials engineering. Another promising direction is the development of interpretable AI models that elucidate the mechanisms underlying HEM properties, enabling researchers to refine compositions strategically. This data-driven, systematic approach moves beyond trial-and-error methods, expediting the creation of next-generation HEMs tailored for SOCs. (f) Economic viability and long-term cost benefits: Economically, the high stability and durability of HEMs present potential for long-term cost savings, as these materials could reduce the need for frequent replacements and maintenance. However, this potential needs to be quantified through cost-benefit analyses to assess HEMs’ economic feasibility compared to conventional materials, emphasizing their advantages in large-scale applications. Additionally, HEMs present unique challenges in recycling due to their complex compositions. Emerging techniques in material recovery, such as advanced chemical separation methods and efficient recycling technologies, will be essential to address these challenges. In addition to economic factors, the environmental impact of HEM disposal and potential benefits of sustainable recycling practices are paramount. Without proper end-of-life processes, these complex materials may contribute to environmental degradation. Developing effective recycling solutions will not only mitigate disposal concerns but also contribute to the feasibility of a circular economy for HEMs. By prioritizing the reuse of worn-out components and minimizing resource extraction, a circular approach could enhance the sustainability of HEM-based SOC technology, aligning it more closely with environmentally responsible and economically viable practices. (g) Challenges for the transition of HEMs to industrial applications: The unique properties of HEMs, such as their enhanced stability, durability, and performance, present significant opportunities for their transition from academic research to practical, industrial-scale applications, particularly in renewable energy systems. However, this advancement is accompanied by several challenges. One primary issue is the complexity of synthesis; large-scale production demands precise control over multi-element composition and high purity, which are often difficult to achieve consistently and affordably with existing methods. Furthermore, the high costs and technical requirements of scalable synthesis can limit the feasibility of HEMs in applications that require long-term stability and reliability. To address these challenges, it will be essential to develop cost-effective and scalable synthesis techniques while optimizing production processes to enhance yield and efficiency. Additionally, fostering collaboration between academia and industry will be critical in refining HEM fabrication methods to meet the specific needs of industrial applications, including durability, ease of integration, and minimal environmental impact. By overcoming these hurdles, HEMs can fulfill their potential in advancing renewable energy technologies and contribute to a more sustainable future. Overall, HEMs represent a promising new frontier for developing high-performance, durable SOC components. Continued research into the relationship between configurational entropy, material structure, and electrochemical performance will be essential to unlocking their full potential. With advances in synthesis techniques and a deeper understanding of entropy stabilization, HEMs are poised to play a key role in the commercialization and long-term success of SOC technologies. Guangming Yang is an associate professor at the School of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, China. He obtained his PhD degree from Nanjing Tech University in 2016 and then joined Zongping Shao’s group. His research interests focus on designing and synthesizing perovskite materials and their applications in high-temperature electrochemical devices. Zongping Shao is a John Curtin Distinguished Professor at Curtin University, Australia. He received his PhD degree from Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, China, in 2000. He worked as a Visiting Scholar at Institut de Researches Sur La Catalyse, CNRS, France, and then as a Postdoctoral Fellow at California Institute of Technology, USA, from 2000 to 2005. His current research interests include fuel cells, lithium-ion batteries, metal–air batteries, solar cells, and oxygen-permeable membranes. He has published >800 international journal papers with a total citation of >73,000 and an H-index of 131 (Google Scholar). He was selected as one of the highly cited researchers (2014, 2017–2024) by Clarivate Analytics.

coredata.dc:description: As global energy demand increases and environmental standards tighten, the development of efficient, eco-friendly energy conversion and storage technologies becomes crucial. Solid oxide cells (SOCs) show great promise because of their high energy conversion efficiency and wide range of applications. High-entropy materials (HEMs), a novel class of materials comprising several principal elements, have attracted significant interest within the materials science and energy sectors. Their distinctive structural features and adaptable functional properties offer immense potential for innovation across various applications. This review systematically covers the basic concepts, crystal structures, element selection, and major synthesis strategies of HEMs, and explores in detail the specific applications of these materials in SOCs, including its potential as air electrodes, fuel electrodes, electrolytes, and interconnects (including barrier coatings). By analyzing existing studies, this review reveals the significant advantages of HEMs in enhancing the performance, anti-poisoning, and stability of SOCs; highlights the key areas and challenges for future research; and looks into possible future directions.
